68.155(f) Safety Improvements
The facility has evaluated the recommendations from the PHA revalidation completed in October of 2017 and the compliance audit conducted in July 2016.  Any improvements made in response to the recommendations were documented and added to the PSM/RMP documentation.

Conclusion

As part of WQD's commitment to safety and respect for the hazards associated with handling and storing chlorine, WQD had a chlorine management system in place prior to the EPA RMP mandate.  To comply with RMP,WQD re-evaluated systems for handling chlorine and updated and modified elements as necessary and continue RMP related practices on a regular basis.  The RMP eSubmit satisfies WQD's requirement to fully update and re-submit to EPA a summary of their Risk Management Program for the chlorine system every five(5)years.

68.155(c) Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Prevention Program required for compliance with 40 CFR Part 68 for Program 3 processes is identical to the prevention program required under OSHA PSM.  WQD aligned its prevention program with OSHA in 1999.  WQD continuously evaluates and updates safety and prevention procedures as needed.  WQD prepared a process hazard analysis for the chlorine system as part the development of the Risk Management Plan.

68.155(d) Five-year Accident History
The chlorination facility has been in place since 1915.  No accidents, as described under 40 CFR 68.42(a), have occurred at this facility since it began operation.

68.155(e) Emergency Response Program
The emergency response program established by WQD does not require personnel to act as the site incident commander. Release scenarios and distances to toxic endpoints are discussed in more detail in the subsequent paragraphs.

Worst-Case Release Scenario
Worst-Case Release Scenario is determined in accordance with the requirements provided in 40 CFR 68.22 and 40 CFR 68.25(b,c). 

As described in USEPA 40 CFR Part 68.25(b) the worst-case release shall be the greater of the following:

1. The greatest amount held in a single vessel or
2. The greatest amount in a pipe.  

For the chlorine process at the Billings Water Treatment Plant the worst-case release is if a 1-ton cylinder (maximum amount held in a single vessel) of chlorine ruptures and its contents escape to the atmosphere in 10 minutes.  In the event the 1-ton cylinder would release its entire contents to the atmosphere in 10 minutes the release rate would be 200 pounds per minute.  The distance to the toxic end point worst-case release distance was calculated with the EPA dispersion modeling program RMPComp.

The residential population within the 0.90-mile radius of influence was determined to be approximately 1262.  The Yellowstone County G.I.S. provided the population within the radius of influence.  A map showing the impact zone radius is included in the facility RMP manual.

Chlorine for the chlorination process is stored in ton containers.  Normally eight ton containers are connected during the summer months and four ton containers are connected during the winter months.  Our present chlorine supplier is located in Denver, Colorado. The chlorination facilities are contained within the confines of the secure water treatment plant site. This prevents unauthorized personnel from accessing the area. WQD maintains chlorine leak detection devices through out the chlorine storage and chlorinator rooms.  There are audible and visual alarms in the building and a nearby administration building in addition to the alarms being monitored in the main control room.

68.155(c) Offsite Consequence Analysis
One worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario were assessed for the chlorine process.  To ensure a common basis for comparisons, EPA defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint.  The alternative release rate is a release that is considered more reasonable or more likely.  Active mitigation measures can be used in determining the alternative release scenario while the worst-case scenario only allows consideration of passive mitigation measures.
 
The toxic endpoint for chlorine has been defined by EPA to be 0.0087 mg/L (3 ppm).  This airborne concentration that is used as the toxic endpoint is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects.

Executive Summary
USEPA 40 CFR Part 68
Subpart G


Introduction

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations 40 CFR Part 68, require facilities that have a regulated substance above the listed threshold quantities to develop a formal Risk Management Program.  EPA also requires these facilities to register and submit a Risk Management Plan using RMP*Submit  by June 21, 1999.  Billings Public Works Department, Water Quality Division(WQD) maintains quantities of chlorine above the RMP threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds and as such is subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.  A hazard review was completed to determine the RMP program level applicable to WQD's chlorine system. 

The information presented in this section is intended to describe the elements of WQD's Risk Management Program.  The format of the section corresponds to the executive summary data elements as dictated in 40 CFR Part 68 Executive Summary Section.  

Executive Summary Data Elements

According to EPA guidance the executive summary must include a brief description of the facility's Risk Management Program.  The following sections list each of the required executive summary data elements by rule citation. 
68.155(a) Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
Billings Public Works Department Water Quality Division (WQD) has operated their chlorination system without incident since its purchase in 1915. This successful operating record is due to WQD's commitment to training programs, operating procedures, and maintenance activities.  

68.155(b) Stationary Source and the Substance Handled
Billings Public Works Department, Water Quality Divsion operates a 65-MGD municipal water treatment plant near the Yellowstone River in the south central portion of the city.
